prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote this is in the wrong. The scenario is about a guy who's been paying all the bills while his girlfriend works part-time. He's upset because she got upset when he made her pay for a $40 takeout.

First, I need to consider their living arrangement. He pays all the rent and bills, which might be an existing agreement. The incident was a single event where he asked her to cover the takeout because he forgot his wallet. She reacted negatively, which he found ugly and put out. 

He argues that she should start contributing more. But is he in the wrong? Well, he's pointing out her part-time income. If she's already contributing with her income, maybe through other ways like utilities or groceries? The problem is that he's making her pay for a single incident without prior discussion. 

Financial expectations in a relationship can be subjective. If they haven't had a conversation about splitting expenses, he's making a unilateral decision here. The fact that he's upset about her reaction might indicate that he hasn't communicated his expectations clearly. 

Also, $40 for takeout isn't a huge amount, but her reaction might stem from feeling it's unfair if she's not contributing to other bills. Maybe she feels he's singling her out because he's been paying everything else. 

He's using this incident as a reason to make her pay more bills in general. But is that fair? If they live together, splitting bills should be discussed. If he hasn't talked about it before, this might be a sudden change without mutual agreement. 

So, the author might be in the wrong if he's not considering her feelings and the existing financial setup. He's reacting to a single incident and using it to justify changing the financial responsibilities without prior discussion. That could be seen as unfair or abrupt.
